message.content:
We must “net‐up” all of the individual interest receivable transactions – that is, add up (with sign) all the “Interest Receivables” amounts from the data. (In the operating section using the indirect method an increase in an asset is “deducted” from net income.) In our file the only rows that affect the interest receivable footing are those whose “type” is “Interest Receivables.”

In our problem data the following rows contribute and their “amount” values are (with duplicates shown grouped):

• Two rows of 445.00                         → 445.00×2  = 890.00  
• Two rows of ≈404.49212704            → 404.49212704×2 = 808.98  
• Four rows of ≈348.48620704              → 348.48620704×4 = 1393.94  
• Four rows of ≈279.87037099                → 279.87037099×4 = 1119.48  
• Nine rows of ≈146.75789479                → 146.75789479×9 ≈ 1320.82  
• Ten rows of ≈91.10276028                 → 91.10276028×10 = 911.03  
• One row of ≈49.75595374  
 
If you add these numbers step‐by‐step you get:
  890.00 + 808.98 = 1698.98  
  1698.98 + 1393.94 = 3092.92  
  3092.92 + 1119.48 = 4212.40  
  4212.40 + 1320.82 = 5533.22  
  5533.22 + 911.03  = 6444.25  
  6444.25 + 49.76   = 6494.01    (approximately)

Since “Interest Receivables” is an asset account, an increase of 6494.01 means that, on the cash‐flow statement (using the indirect method) this represents a use of cash (a “decrease” in cash when adjusting net income). Therefore the “(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable” is –6494.01 (rounded to two decimals).

We now present the answer in the requested json format.

────────────────────────────
  
{
  "solution": {
    "(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable": "-6494.01"
  }
}
